author_bibliography.author: Arthur Schopenhauer
author_bibliography.description: Arthur Schopenhauer was a German philosopher best known for his pessimistic philosophy and metaphysical analysis of the will. His work profoundly influenced existentialism, psychoanalysis, literature, and modern philosophy, especially through his central concept of the 'will to live' as the irrational force behind all existence.
author_bibliography.background: Born in Danzig (now Gdańsk, Poland), Schopenhauer was educated in classical literature, science, and philosophy. Deeply influenced by Kant, the Upanishads, and Buddhism, he developed a unique system centered around the idea that blind, insatiable will is the essence of reality. Though largely unrecognized in his lifetime, he later became one of the most influential thinkers of the 19th and 20th centuries.

works.title: On the Fourfold Root of the Principle of Sufficient Reason
works.original_title: Über die vierfache Wurzel des Satzes vom zureichenden Grunde
works.summary: Schopenhauer's doctoral dissertation, which analyzes the principle that nothing happens without a reason. It distinguishes four types of rational explanation and sets the groundwork for his later metaphysics.

works.title: The World as Will and Representation
works.original_title: Die Welt als Wille und Vorstellung
works.summary: His magnum opus, proposing that the underlying reality of the world is irrational will, and that human experience is merely representation. The work includes discussions on aesthetics, ethics, and asceticism.

works.title: On Vision and Colors
works.original_title: Über das Sehn und die Farben
works.summary: A critique and expansion of Goethe's color theory, this work blends philosophy, perception, and empirical observation, attempting to explain how color arises from the interaction of light and the eye.

works.title: On the Will in Nature
works.original_title: Über den Willen in der Natur
works.summary: An attempt to show how his metaphysical concept of the will is confirmed by scientific discoveries across disciplines like biology, chemistry, and physiology.

works.title: Parerga and Paralipomena
works.summary: A two-volume collection of essays and aphorisms covering diverse topics such as metaphysics, aesthetics, psychology, ethics, and religion. These writings brought Schopenhauer late recognition and influence.

works.title: On the Freedom of the Will
works.original_title: Über die Freiheit des menschlichen Willens
works.summary: An award-winning essay exploring human freedom, determinism, and moral responsibility. Schopenhauer argues that while humans experience themselves as free, their actions are determined by character and motivation.

works.title: On the Basis of Morality
works.summary: A companion essay to 'On the Freedom of the Will', defending compassion as the only true moral motive and critiquing Kantian ethics as abstract and formalistic.

early_period.characteristics: 1810-1818 Focus on epistemology and the foundations of reason; early Kantian influence and metaphysical inquiry into the nature of reality.
early_period.themes: Reason, perception, idealism, foundation of knowledge

middle_period.characteristics: 1819-1840 Development and articulation of core metaphysical and ethical ideas, including the nature of will, suffering, and denial of desire.

late_period.characteristics: 1840-1860 Expansion and popularization of his ideas through essays, aphorisms, and engagement with natural sciences and moral philosophy.
late_period.themes: Compassion, freedom, fate, cultural critique, human nature

major_themes: The Will as the Essence of Reality
Asceticism and Denial of the Will
Compassion as the Basis of Morality
author_bibliography.influence: Schopenhauer’s philosophy deeply influenced Friedrich Nietzsche, Richard Wagner, Sigmund Freud, Thomas Mann, Albert Einstein, and modern existentialist and psychoanalytic thought. His integration of Eastern philosophy into Western metaphysics helped broaden philosophical discourse beyond European traditions.
author_bibliography.note: Though largely ignored in academic circles during his early career, Schopenhauer’s later recognition led to a lasting impact on literature, psychology, and existential philosophy. His aphoristic style and cultural pessimism continue to resonate in critiques of modernity and human suffering.
